verses.text: Then Moses went and spoke these words to all Israel.
verses.comment: Narrative transition, no significant changes.

verses.text: He said to them, "I am now one hundred and twenty years old; I am no longer able to go out and come in. And the LORD has said to me, 'You shall not cross over this Jordan.'"
verses.comment: "Go out and come in" means to lead as before. Age and God's decree referenced.

verses.text: The LORD your God himself will cross over before you; he will destroy these nations before you, and you shall dispossess them. Joshua will cross over before you, as the LORD has said.
verses.comment: The LORD and Joshua will lead Israel into the land.

verses.text: And the LORD will do to them as he did to Sihon and Og, kings of the Amorites, and to their land, whom he destroyed.
verses.comment: Reference to previous victories as assurance.

verses.text: The LORD will deliver them over to you, and you shall do to them according to all the command that I have given you.
verses.comment: Direct command to obey God's instructions concerning conquered peoples.

verses.text: Be strong and courageous; do not fear or be afraid of them, for it is the LORD your God who goes with you. He will not leave you or forsake you."
verses.comment: Key promise of God's presence and faithfulness.

verses.text: Then Moses called Joshua and said to him in the sight of all Israel, "Be strong and courageous, for you shall go with this people into the land that the LORD has sworn to their fathers to give them, and you shall cause them to inherit it."
verses.comment: Public charge to Joshua mirrors earlier encouragement.

verses.text: It is the LORD who goes before you. He will be with you; he will not leave you or forsake you. Do not fear or be discouraged."
verses.comment: Restatement of God's unfailing presence.

verses.text: And Moses wrote this law and gave it to the priests, the sons of Levi, who carried the ark of the covenant of the LORD, and to all the elders of Israel.
verses.comment: Moses records Torah for priests and elders.

verses.text: And Moses commanded them, "At the end of every seven years, at the appointed time in the year of release, at the Feast of Booths,
verses.comment: "Year of release" refers to sabbatical year, "Feast of Booths" is Sukkot.

verses.text: when all Israel comes to appear before the LORD your God at the place he will choose, you shall read this law before all Israel in their hearing.
verses.comment: Requirement to read Torah publicly.

verses.text: Assemble the people—men, women, and little ones, and the sojourner within your towns—that they may hear and learn to fear the LORD your God, and be careful to do all the words of this law.
verses.comment: "Sojourner" does not refer to 'inclusive' outsider but resident foreigner.

verses.text: And that their children, who have not known it, may hear and learn to fear the LORD your God, as long as you live in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess."
verses.comment: Emphasis on generational learning.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Behold, the day of your death is near. Call Joshua and present yourselves in the tent of meeting, so that I may commission him." So Moses and Joshua went and presented themselves in the tent of meeting.
verses.comment: Joshua is appointed in God's presence.

verses.text: And the LORD appeared in the tent in a pillar of cloud, and the pillar of cloud stood over the entrance of the tent.
verses.comment: Theophany depicted as cloud.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses, "Behold, you are about to lie down with your fathers. Then this people will rise and prostitute themselves after the foreign gods of the land into which they are going, and they will abandon me and break my covenant which I have made with them.
verses.comment: "Prostitute themselves" means spiritual unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Then my anger will be kindled against them in that day, and I will forsake them and hide my face from them, and they will be devoured. And many evils and troubles will find them, so that they will say in that day, 'Have not these evils come upon us because our God is not among us?'
verses.comment: Hiding God's face symbolizes rejection/absence.

verses.text: And I will surely hide my face in that day because of all the evil that they have done, because they have turned to other gods.
verses.comment: Repeated for emphasis; punishment for idolatry.

verses.text: "Now, therefore, write this song and teach it to the people of Israel. Put it in their mouths, that this song may be a witness for me against the people of Israel.
verses.comment: "This song" is the Song of Moses, next chapter.

verses.text: For when I have brought them into the land flowing with milk and honey, which I swore to give to their fathers, and they have eaten and are full and grown fat, they will turn to other gods and serve them, and despise me and break my covenant.
verses.comment: "Land flowing with milk and honey" idiom for abundance.

verses.text: And when many evils and troubles have come upon them, this song shall confront them as a witness, for it will not be forgotten out of the mouths of their descendants. For I know what they are inclined to do even today, before I have brought them into the land that I swore to give."
verses.comment: God's foreknowledge and song as legal testimony.

verses.text: So Moses wrote this song the same day and taught it to the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Verse sets up the next chapter, no changes.

verses.text: And the LORD commissioned Joshua the son of Nun and said, "Be strong and courageous, for you shall bring the people of Israel into the land that I swore to them. I will be with you."
verses.comment: Divine endorsement and repetition of promise.

verses.text: When Moses had finished writing the words of this law in a book, to the very end,
verses.comment: Completion of Torah manuscript.

verses.text: Moses commanded the Levites who carried the ark of the covenant of the LORD:
verses.comment: Direct charge to the Levitical priests.

verses.text: "Take this book of the law and put it by the side of the ark of the covenant of the LORD your God, so that it may be there as a witness against you.
verses.comment: Book stored next to, not inside, the ark.

verses.text: For I know how rebellious and stubborn you are. Behold, even today, while I am still alive among you, you have been rebellious against the LORD; how much more after my death!
verses.comment: Moses laments Israel's stubbornness.

verses.text: "Assemble to me all the elders of your tribes and your officers, so that I may speak these words in their hearing and call heaven and earth to witness against them.
verses.comment: "Heaven and earth" is formulaic for universal witness.

verses.text: For I know that after my death you will surely act corruptly and turn aside from the way that I have commanded you. And in days to come evil will befall you, because you will do what is evil in the sight of the LORD, provoking him to anger through the work of your hands."
verses.comment: "Work of your hands" means idolatry and disobedience.

verses.text: Then Moses spoke the words of this song in the hearing of all the assembly of Israel.
verses.comment: Final verse introduces the Song of Moses.
